thread_showcases.title: In the category of sets epimorphisms are surjective - Constructive Proof?
thread_showcases.question_excerpt: The statement that surjective maps are epimorphisms in the category of sets can be shown in a constructive way. What about the inverse? Is it possible to show that every epimorphism in the category of sets is surjective without reverting to a proof by contradiction / negation?
thread_showcases.answer_excerpt: Theorem: Every epi is surjective. Proof. Let $h : A \to B$ be an epimorphism. We define maps $f, g : B \to \mathcal{P}(B)$ by \begin{align*} f(b) &= \{b\} \cap \mathrm{im}(h)\\ g(b) &= \{b\} \end{align*} where we recall that $\mathrm{im}(h) = \{b \in B \mid \exists a \in A \,.\,

thread_showcases.title: is localization of category of categories equivalent to |Cat|

thread_showcases.answer_excerpt: There are set theoretic issues that will hinder any proof of this statement. thread_showcases.title: What is the symbol of a differential operator?
thread_showcases.question_excerpt: I find Wikipedia's discussion of symbols of differential operators a bit impenetrable, and Google doesn't seem to turn up useful links, so I'm hoping someone can point me to a more pedantic discussion. Background I think I understand the basic idea on $\mathbb{R}^n$ , so for read
thread_showcases.answer_excerpt: The principal symbol of a differential operator $\sum_{|\alpha| \leq m} a_\alpha(x) \partial_x^\alpha$ is by definition the function $\sum_{|\alpha| = m} a_\alpha(x) (i\xi)^\alpha$ Here $\alpha$ is a multi-index (so $\partial_x^\alpha$ denotes $\alpha_1$ derivatives with respect

thread_showcases.title: Limit of a double integral
thread_showcases.question_excerpt: What is the $\varepsilon\to 0$ limit of the following double integral $$\int\limits_{-1}^1d\tau\;\sqrt{1-\tau^2}\;\tau\int\limits_0^\infty dq\;q^2e^{iq(\tau+i\varepsilon)}\;?$$ I was asked about this integral by my friend who got it in a physics research project.
